Ammonia, as a promising hydrogen carrier, has garnered significant attention due to its high energy density, ease of transportation, and non-toxic decomposition process, and the absence of harmful by-products. Ammonia can produce hydrogen through the thermochemical ammonia decomposition reaction, requiring efficient catalysts. Although Ru-based catalysts exhibit high activity, their application is limited due to their high cost and scarcity. Here, a series of highly efficient and stable non-noble CoM@NC (M = Ni, Mo) bimetallic catalysts with N-doped carbon frameworks embedded in ZIF-67 templates are synthesized for ammonia decomposition to hydrogen. The impact of non-noble metal composition and ratios on the performance of ammonia decomposition is primarily investigated. The experimental results show that: 1) The catalytic performance of the ammonia decomposition catalyst can be regulated by adjusting the catalyst composition and metal ratios; 2) Compared to CoNi@NC catalysts, CoMo@NC catalysts exhibit superior performance in ammonia decomposition; 3) Co1Mo1@NC catalyst achieves an ammonia conversion rate of 97.57 % at 550 °C under the conditions of 30,000 mL h-1 g-1 cat, with a hydrogen production rate of 32.66 mmol H2 g-1 cat min-1; 4) Even in extreme conditions of 600 °C and 60,000 mL h-1 g-1 cat for 300 h, the ammonia decomposition activity of the Co1Mo1@NC catalyst remains unchanged; 5) The excellent catalytic performance of Co1Mo1@NC catalyst is attributed to its porous layered petal-like structure providing a fast pathway for electron transfer, the presence of Co3Mo3 N bimetallic nitride with more Mo-N active sites, and its strong alkaline nature. This study offers significant importance for the further development of non-noble metal cobalt-based catalysts for ammonia decomposition. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ammonia decomposition Cobalt-based catalysts Non-noble metal catalysts Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction With the ever-increasing global energy demand and the rapid depletion of fossil fuels at an alarming rate, coupled with the severe environmental pollution caused by greenhouse gas emissions, meeting our energy needs through conventional sources has become exceedingly challenging [1]. Hydrogen, as an environmentally friendly and sustainable energy source, is considered a crucial component of the future energy landscape, poised to meet the demand for clean energy. It has gained widespread attention globally, and the launch of global strategic projects for green hydrogen production signifies the prosperity of the hydrogen economy [2]. However, hydrogen gas has a low volumetric energy density, and its liquefaction is an energy-intensive process that can consume up to one-third of the energy it can carry [3]. Additionally, hydrogen gas is a colorless, odorless, and highly flammable substance, and the large-scale storage and transportation of hydrogen still face significant technological barriers and safety risks. Furthermore, encapsulating and maintaining the liquefaction of hydrogen requires substantial energy and specialized refrigeration systems, leading to increased costs and energy losses [4]. In the face of these challenges, ammonia (NH3) is considered a promising alternative as a hydrogen carrier, offering high energy and storage density, low-cost and easy liquefaction [5,6], and narrow flammability range [4]. The ammonia decomposition reaction is a promising hydrogen production technology under high temperature and low-pressure conditions, requiring temperatures as high as 600 °C for complete decomposition [7]. Therefore, the development of efficient and stable catalysts is crucial. Among all the materials used for NH3 decomposition, Ru-based catalysts are widely recognized as the best candidate due to their suitable Ru-N bonding energy [8,9]. In addition to Ru, other noble metals such as Pt, Pd and Ir also exhibit promising performance in NH₃ decomposition [10–12]. However, their widespread application is hindered by high cost and scarcity [13,14]. To overcome reliance on noble metals, extensive research has been conducted to develop numerous cost-effective non- noble metal catalysts (e.g., Co, Ni, Fe, or Mo) supported on high-surface-area carriers (e.g., carbon nanotubes, CeO2, Al2O3, or SiO2) for promoting ammonia decomposition and hydrogen production [15–20]. Among the numerous existing catalysts, bimetallic catalysts such as CoNi [17,21],CoFe [22],CoMo [23,24], featuring selected carriers and promoters, have been identified as promising candidates for enhancing ammonia decomposition reaction performance. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), which are crystalline or amorphous coordination compounds composed of inorganic nodes coordinated by organic ligands, are considered as ideal catalyst supports due to their remarkable compositional diversity, high specific surface area, and porosity [25]. Li et al. [26] utilized metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) as templates to fabricate highly active Ru-based catalysts for ammonia decomposition. They achieved molecular-level interactions between the Ru precursor and the support, protecting and dispersing the active Ru sites, resulting in enhanced catalytic activity. ZIF-67, a commonly used subclass of MOFs, exhibits excellent chemical stability and ease of synthesis. With its large specific surface area, high porosity, large pore volume, highly regular topology, and porous structure, ZIF-67 is widely used in the fields of supercapacitors, electrocatalysts, pollutant degradation, and synergistic therapy [27–30]. Hence, ZIF-67 is an ideal candidate catalyst for ammonia decomposition for hydrogen production due to its abundance of cobalt and controllable interior cavities. Li et al. [31] used ZIF-67 as a template and thermally decomposed it in a nitrogen atmosphere to obtain Co@NC, with small-sized cobalt nanoparticles dispersed on a nitrogen-doped carbon support. Among them, the Co/NC-600 catalyst exhibited an 80 % ammonia conversion rate at 500 °C. In the field of bimetallic catalysts, Lei et al. [32] reported a CoNi@NC alloy catalyst derived from ZIF-67. The enrichment of active sites from the derived structure of ZIF-67 and the introduction of nickel provided it with ideal electrocatalytic performance, suitable for the electrochemical reduction of nitrates. To the best of our knowledge, there have been no reports on bimetallic catalysts derived from ZIF-67 specifically for ammonia decomposition. In this study, a series of CoM (M = Ni, Mo) bimetallic zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF) with different ratios were synthesized. Subsequently, the CoM-ZIF were pyrolyzed in a 10 % H2 (balanced with Ar) atmosphere at 700 °C to generate a range of CoM@NC bimetallic catalysts embedded in nitrogen-doped carbon frameworks for hydrogen production via ammonia decomposition. The impact on the catalytic performance is investigated by adjusting the metal components and their ratios. The experimental results show that Co1Mo1@NC catalyst achieves an ammonia conversion of 97.57 % at 550 °C with a space velocity of 30,000 mL h-1 g-1 cat, corresponding to a hydrogen production rate of 32.66 mmol H2 g-1 cat min-1. Remarkably, even under extreme conditions of 600 °C and a space velocity of 60,000 mL h-1 g-1 cat for 300 h, no significant degradation in the ammonia decomposition activity of the Co1Mo1@NC catalyst is observed. These results indicate the Co1Mo1@NC catalyst exhibits satisfactory ammonia decomposition efficiency and excellent durability compared to most previously reported Co-based catalysts for ammonia decomposition and hydrogen generation. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Preparation of the catalysts The chemicals used in this study, including methanol (99 %), sodium molybdenum (MoNa2O4), ethanol (99 %), 2-methylimidazole (C4H6N2, >98 %), zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O), cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O) and nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O)are purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used as received without any further purification. Washing is achieved with ultrapure water and reagent grade ethanol and methanol where required. Ultrapure water is used for solution preparations. Synthesis of ZIF67: In a typical synthesis, 3.94 g of 2-methylimidazole is dissolved in a mixed solution of 40 ml of methanol and 40 ml of ethanol. Separately, 3.492 g cobalt nitrate hexahydrate is dissolved in another mixed solution of 40 ml of methanol and 40 ml of ethanol. The above two solutions are then mixed under continuous stirring for 10 s, and the final solution is kept for 20 h at room temperature. The resulting purple precipitates are collected by centrifugation, washed with methanol and ethanol three times, and finally dried under vacuum conditions at a temperature of 80 °C for 12 h. Synthesis of Co1Mo1-ZIF: 1.2 g of sodium molybdate is dissolved in 20 mL deionized water to form a solution. 160 mg ZIF-67 is dissolved in 60 mL of methanol. Drop sodium molybdate solution into ZIF-67 solution and at 80 °C for 2 h. The resulting amaranth precipitates are collected by centrifugation, washed with methanol and ethanol three times, and finally dried under vacuum conditions at a temperature of 80 °C for 12 h. For detailed information on the synthesis of other catalyst components, please refer to the Supplementary Information. Synthesis of CoM@NC (Ni,Mo) :The prepared CoM-ZIF (Ni, Mo) nanoparticles are thermally reduced in a tubular furnace at a heating rate of 5 °C/min under 10 % H2 (balanced with Ar) at 700 °C for 2 h. The resulting catalyst is denoted as CoM@NC (Ni, Mo). 2.2 Characterizations X-ray Powder Diffraction (XRD): The X-ray powder diffraction measurements are performed on a D8 Advance powder X-ray diffractometer equipped with a Cu X-ray source. The operating conditions are set at 30 kV and 30 mA for the X-ray tube. The scanning range is from 5° to 80° with a step size of 0.02° X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS): In-situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy measurements are performed using the Thermo Scientific K-Alpha instrument. The excitation source used is Al Kα radiation with a photon energy of 1486.6 eV The instrument is operated at 15 keV and 150 W. Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-OES): The contents of Co, Ni, and Mo in the catalyst are determined using the Agilent 5800 ICP-OES instrument. Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM): SEM observations are performed using a Hitachi SU8020. The accelerating voltage is set at 10 kV, and the morphology is observed at magnifications ranging from 25 × 103 to 40 × 103. Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM): TEM characterization of the samples is conducted on the FEI Talos F200S field-emission transmission electron microscope. The elemental mapping results are obtained using Energy-Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDS) analysis integrated with the transmission electron microscope. Hydrogen Temperature-Programmed Reduction (H2-TPR): The H2-TPR measurements are carried out using the Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 instrument. The prepared catalyst (30 mg) is pretreated in a high-purity nitrogen atmosphere at 300 °C for 30 min, followed by cooling to room temperature under the same nitrogen atmosphere. The atmosphere is then switched to a 10 % H2/Ar mixture, and the pretreated catalyst is subjected to a temperature ramp from 50 °C to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Nitrogen Adsorption-Desorption Test (BET Surface Area): The nitrogen adsorption-desorption measurements are performed on the Quantachrome Autosorb IQ gas adsorption analyzer. Prior to the measurement, the sample is subjected to a 6-hour degassing treatment at 200 °C. The N2 adsorption measurement is then conducted at −196 °C. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) theory is used to calculate the specific surface area by determining the adsorbed volume at a relative pressure (p/p0) of 0.99. Carbon Dioxide Temperature-Programmed Desorption (CO2-TPD): The CO2-TPD measurements are conducted using the Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 instrument. 50 mg sample is placed in a reaction tube and dried and pretreated by ramping the temperature from room temperature to 50 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a helium flow (30 mL/min) for 1 hour. The sample is then cooled to 50 °C and exposed to a 10 % CO2/He mixture (30 mL/min) for 1 hour until saturation. After that, a helium flow (30 mL/min) is introduced for 1 h to remove weakly physisorbed CO2 on the surface. Finally, the temperature is increased to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a helium atmosphere, and the desorbed gases were monitored using a Thermal Conductivity Detector. 3.3 Catalyst performance evaluation The ammonia decomposition performance of the catalyst is evaluated in a fixed-bed reactor at atmospheric pressure. 100 mg of catalyst is placed in a quartz tube with a length of 500 mm, an outer diameter of 6 mm, and an inner diameter of 5 mm. Quartz wool is used to fix the catalyst at both ends of the tube to prevent powder detachment during the testing, as shown in Fig. S1. High-purity argon gas is used as the purge gas, and the feed gas is switched to 99.99 % pure NH3 at the target temperature. The online analysis of ammonia decomposition conversion is carried out using a gas chromatograph (GC 4000 A) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. High-purity argon gas is used as the carrier gas for the chromatograph, and a Porapark N column is utilized. A mass flow controller is used at the inlet to control the gas flow rate, while a calibrated mass flow meter is used at the outlet to measure the flow rates of nitrogen and hydrogen. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) is set at 30,000 mL h-1 g-1 cat for catalytic activity testing. The testing temperature ranges from 300 °C to 600 °C, with data points taken at 50 °C intervals, and each target temperature is maintained for 60 min to reach a steady state. The durability test of the catalyst is conducted in the same setup, with the reacted catalyst continuously tested for 300 h, and the GHSV set at 60,000 mL h-1 g-1 cat during this period. Ammonia decomposition conversion rate is calculated as follows: (1) X N H 3 = A N H 3 , in − A N H 3 , out A N H 3 , in × 100 % Where X N H 3 is the conversion rate of N H 3 , A N H 3 , out and A N H 3 , in represent molar flow rate of outlet and inlet gas, respectively. Hydrogen generation rate is calculated as follows: (2) H 2 formation rate ( mmol g cat − 1 mi n − 1 ) = 50 / 22 . 4 × X N H 3 × 1 . 5 m c a t 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Ammonia decomposition performance The ammonia decomposition activity and hydrogen production rate of Co1 M1@NC (M = Ni, Mo) bimetallic catalysts were compared to Co@NC under a space velocity of 30,000 mL h-1 g-1 cat. As shown in Fig. 1 a, all catalysts exhibit negligible activity below 300 °C. However, as the temperature increases, ammonia conversion gradually rises, reaching over 80 % at 600 °C for all catalysts. The activity follows the trend: Co1Mo1@NC > Co1Ni1@NC > Co@NC. Notably, Co1Mo1@NC outperforms Co1Ni1@NC across the entire temperature range, with both bimetallic catalysts showing significantly enhanced activity compared to Co@NC. These results demonstrate that the introduction of Ni and Mo significantly improves the catalytic performance of Co@NC. The hydrogen production rates (Fig. 1b) show a similar trend to the ammonia decomposition activities. Under the testing condition of 30,000 mL h-1 g-1 cat, Co1Mo1@NC achieves ammonia conversion rates of 88.78 %, 97.57 %, and 98.90 % at 500 °C, 550 °C, and 600 °C, respectively, with corresponding hydrogen production rates of 29.73, 32.66, and 33.11 mmol H2 g-1 cat min-1. The Co1Ni1@NC and Co1Mo1@NC bimetallic catalysts show significantly higher catalytic activity than their monometallic counterparts, prompting further investigation into the ammonia decomposition performance of these catalysts with different metal ratios. The metal loadings in the catalysts were determined using ICP-OES (Table S1). Fig. 1c shows the catalytic activity of CoNi@NC catalysts with various metal ratios. All CoNi@NC catalysts outperform Co@NC, regardless of the metal ratio, with the activity order: Co1Ni1@NC > Co2Ni1@NC > Co1Ni2@NC. Notably, Co1Ni1@NC demonstrates an 18.70 % improvement in catalytic activity at 500 °C compared to Co@NC. Fig. 1d presents the catalytic activity of CoMo@NC catalysts with different compositions. CoMo@NC catalysts exhibit superior performance compared to Co@NC, with the activity order: Co1Mo1@NC > Co1Mo2@NC > Co2Mo1@NC. NH₃ conversion rates at 500 °C are 88.78 %, 78.48 %, and 77.04 %, respectively. Co1Mo1@NC shows a 28.65 % increase in catalytic activity compared to Co@NC. Both CoNi@NC and CoMo@NC catalysts exhibit ammonia decomposition performance above 95 % at 600 °C, but CoNi@NC deteriorates more rapidly as the temperature decreases. Within the range of 400–550 °C, Co1Mo1@NC significantly outperforms other catalysts. Compared to reported cobalt-based catalysts in the literature (Table 1 ), Co1Mo1@NC and Co1Ni1@NC show superior performance, with Co1Mo1@NC achieving 88.78 % conversion at 500 °C, and both Co1Mo1@NC and Co1Ni1@NC exceeding 95 % at 550 °C, highlighting their potential for practical applications in ammonia decomposition. To further investigate the enhanced catalytic performance, the apparent activation energies of the catalysts were evaluated. The apparent activation energies of Co2Ni1@NC, Co1Ni1@NC, Co1Ni2@NC, Co2Mo1@NC, Co1Mo1@NC, and Co1Mo2@NC catalysts are 73.33 kJ/mol, 71.50 kJ/mol, 75.49 kJ/mol, 80.73 kJ/mol, 69.17 kJ/mol, and 73.08 kJ/mol, respectively (Figs. 1e and 1f). These results show that Co1Mo1@NC has the lowest activation energy (69.17 kJ/mol), significantly reducing the activation energy for ammonia decomposition and enhancing its performance, comparable to Ru-based catalysts [33–35].Moreover, continuous testing of Co1Mo1@NC at 600 °C and 60,000 mL h-1 g-1 cat for 300 h demonstrates no significant decrease in activity, indicating its excellent stability (Fig. 1g). 3.2 Characterizations Phase analysis of catalysts is an important approach to analyze the reasons behind the enhancement of their catalytic performance. Fig. 2 shows the XRD spectra of the synthesized samples. As shown in Figs. 2a and 2b, the CoNi-ZIF and CoMo-ZIF samples exhibit strong and sharp diffraction peaks without any other impurity peaks, indicating successful synthesis and high crystallinity. The positions of the diffraction peaks for both samples are similar, suggesting similar crystal structures. The CoNi-ZIF samples treated with nickel salts show no significant new peaks compared to the standard ZIF-67, and the intensities of the diffraction peaks slightly decrease with increasing nickel content, indicating similar crystal structures. The XRD spectra of ZIF-67 with different proportions of molybdenum salts show similar diffraction peak positions, suggesting no significant change in crystal structure. However, there is a noticeable change in diffraction intensity with increasing Mo content. As shown in Figs. 2c and 2d, the CoNi@NC and CoMo@NC samples, compared to the untreated CoNi-ZIF and CoMo-ZIF samples, completely lose their sharp diffraction peaks, indicating the formation of corresponding metallic phases and successful reaction preparation. The CoNi@NC sample exhibits new peaks at 44.44°, 51.77°, and 76.51°, with three distinct peaks located between the Co (PDF#15–0806) and Ni (PDF#04–0850) peaks. Typically, the XRD peaks of metal alloys are located between the corresponding peaks of the two pure metals [45,46]. As the nickel content increases, the position of the diffraction peaks remains unchanged, while the peak intensity gradually increases. These diffraction peaks correspond to the (111), (200), and (220) planes of CoNi alloy, which are in excellent agreement with the previously reported CoNi alloy data [47]. In CoMo@NC samples with different molybdenum salt contents, the diffraction peaks correspond to Co (PDF#15–0806) and Co3Mo3 N (PDF#89–7953). The positions of the peaks at 44.21° and 51.54° match with the (111) and (200) crystal planes of Co. The positions of the peaks at 40.02°, 42.56°, 46.55°, and 72.70° match with the characteristic peaks of Co3Mo3 N, corresponding to the (422), (511), (440), and (822) crystal planes of Co3Mo3 N, respectively. The intensities of the diffraction peaks increase with increasing molybdenum salt content. No peaks corresponding to metallic Mo and CoMo alloy were observed in any of the samples, confirming the presence of stable interstitial structures in the bimetallic nitrides. This stable bimetallic nitride with stable interstitial structures enhances the catalytic performance of CoMo@NC in ammonia decomposition [48]. In order to investigate the evolution of morphology and structure, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) are employed to characterization. As shown in Figs. 3 a and 3b, Co2Ni1-ZIF67 retains the basic rhombic dodecahedron shape of the precursor ZIF67 (Fig. S2), with no significant change in volume but a rougher surface. Similarly, for Co1Ni1-ZIF67 (Figs. 3e and 3f) and Co1Ni2-ZIF67 (Figs. 3i And 3j), an increase in nickel salt results in surface roughening while the average particle size remains around 1 μm. The situation for CoMo-ZIF67 is different. With an increasing amount of molybdenum salt, ZIF67 is completely consumed in the reaction, making it increasingly difficult to maintain the regular rhombic dodecahedron morphology. In the case of Co2Mo1-ZIF (Figs. 3c and 3d), although ZIF67 undergoes an initial reaction, it still retains the basic morphology, but the surface starts to wrinkle and peel. In the case of Co1Mo1-ZIF (Figs. 3g and 3h), a uniform particle size of approximately 1.5 μm with a petal-like structure in the form of a rhombic dodecahedron can be clearly observed. Therefore, the annealed Co1Mo1@NC catalyst retains its layered petal-like structure (Fig S3), which not only provides a fast pathway for electron transfer but also offers abundant reaction sites, thereby significantly enhancing its catalytic performance [50–53]. However, in Co1Mo2-ZIF (Figs 3k and 3l), with an increasing proportion of molybdenum salt, the fibrous substances on the surface become denser, and some of the layered petal structures rupture internally, leading to the disappearance of the basic structure and potential aggregation of the products, which may affect the catalytic performance. The morphology of Co1Ni1-ZIF67 and Co1Mo1-ZIF67 is further characterized using high-resolution transmission electron microscope (TEM) images shown in Figs. 4 a and 4b. The Co1Ni1-ZIF67 catalyst appears thicker with a rough surface, while the Co1Mo1-ZIF67 catalyst is relatively thinner and exhibits a distinct petal-like structure, which is consistent with the observations from SEM images. In the corresponding elemental analysis conducted using energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) confirms the presence of Ni and Mo components, uniformly encapsulated within the rhombic dodecahedron framework composed of Co, C, N, and O elements. Under calcination at 700 °C, the rhombic dodecahedral carbon framework disappears, leading to the aggregation of disorganized particles and the formation of corresponding nanoparticles. Fig. 4c provides a high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) image that further reveals the morphology of Co1Ni1@NC. Lattice fringes corresponding to CoNi alloy with interplanar spacings of 0.177 nm and 0.202 nm, corresponding to (200) and (111) crystal planes, respectively, are measured, consistent with the XRD analysis. Additionally, a clear carbon layer can be observed surrounding each particle, which stabilizes the metal particles and enhances the catalyst's stability. Moreover, the corresponding EDS elemental analysis in Fig. 4e confirms the uniform distribution of N, forming a rhombic carbon matrix derived from the thermal decomposition of the carbon framework. The distribution of Co and Ni overlaps with that of C and N, further confirming the existence of Co1Ni1@NC. SEM and EDX elemental mapping images simultaneously show that the synthesized CoNi alloy nanoparticles are uniformly distributed within the N-doped carbon framework. When these alloys are combined with the carrier, this structure exposes more active M-N sites, enhancing its ammonia decomposition performance. HRTEM image shown in Fig. 4d demonstrates a good match between the lattice fringes of 0.213 nm and 0.175 nm in Co1Mo1@NC catalyst and the (511) and (620) crystal planes of Co3Mo3 N, consistent with the XRD analysis. In the corresponding EDS elemental analysis in Fig. 4f, CoMo, O, C, and N elements are observed to be uniformly distributed within the carbon framework derived from the thermal decomposition of Co1Mo1-ZIF67. This unique structure of Co1Mo1@NC enhances the interaction between metal and nitrogen, thus improving the ammonia decomposition performance. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, pore size distribution, and pore volume have a significant impact on the performance of catalysts. Fig. 5 illustrates the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the CoNi@NC and CoMo@NC catalysts with different compositions. According to the IUPAC classification, the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of Co2Ni1@NC, Co1Ni1@NC, and Co1Ni2@NC in Fig. 5a belong to type IV with H1 hysteresis loops, indicating that the catalysts are mainly composed of micropores and mesopores. The pore size distribution obtained from the isotherms in Fig. 5c further confirms the presence of mesopores. In Fig. 5b, the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of Co2Mo1@NC, Co1Mo1@NC, and Co1Mo2@NC also belong to type IV with H1 hysteresis loops. At higher relative pressures, the capillary condensation becomes steeper, indicating that the catalysts are primarily composed of cylindrical pores that are uniform and relatively large. The uniformly porous structure of CoMo@NC catalysts with fast electron transfer pathways provides significant advantages in ammonia decomposition. The specific surface area (SSA) and average pore size of the catalysts were calculated using the BET method, and the results are listed in Table 2 . Among them, the Co1Ni1@NC catalyst exhibits the highest SSA, attributed to the formation of spherical CoNi alloy particles uniformly dispersed in the carbon framework after thermal reduction, consistent with observations from transmission electron microscopy (Fig S4). This optimal catalyst composition contributes to the highest SSA. On the other hand, the addition of molybdenum salt in CoMo@NC catalysts leads to the aggregation of products, resulting in a decrease in specific surface area and an increase in pore size. Similar observations were confirmed through transmission electron microscopy (Fig S5). However, all samples show relatively high specific surface areas, especially the CoNi@NC catalysts. The larger specific surface area provides more active sites, enhances reactant diffusion rates, and improves contact between reactants and the catalyst, thereby significantly enhancing the performance of ammonia decomposition. XPS analysis is performed to investigate the electronic structure and chemical composition of the catalyst surface, as shown in Fig. 6 a for the Co 2p spectrum. Two pairs of doublets are identified at (778.59 eV, 793.28 eV) and (781.00 eV, 795.61 eV), corresponding to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 of Co0 and Co3+ species, respectively [54,55]. The coexistence of Co0 and Co3+ arises from the partial oxidation of CoNi@NC on the surface during storage. In Fig. 6b, the Ni 2p spectrum exhibits spin-orbit splitting similar to Co 2p, and the peak positions at 852.86 eV and 870.22 eV correspond to Ni0, with binding energies of 858.83 eV and 874.53 eV matching the satellites, without any additional peak corresponding to other states [56]. The N 1 s spectrum in Fig. 6d shows peaks at 398.58 eV for pyridinic N (N-6, N in a 6-membered ring), 400.40 eV for pyrrolic CN (N-5, N in a 5-membered ring), and 401.88 eV for graphitic N (N-G, N in the graphene basal plane) [57]. In the C1 s spectrum in Fig. 6c, the peaks at 284.8 eV and 285.05 eV correspond to the characteristic peaks of CC and CN in Co1Ni1@NC material, indicating the formation of nitrogen-doped carbon framework and the close binding of Ni and Co atoms. This suggests that Co1Ni1@NC potentially interacts synergistically with the same reactant molecules during catalytic reactions and facilitates nitrogen doping, forming metal-N-C (M − N − C, M = CoNi) moieties as active catalytic sites, thus promoting the synergistic effect of nitrogen doping in the Co1Ni1@NC bimetallic catalyst. Similarly, the XPS measurements of Co1Mo1@NC confirm the presence of Co, Mo, C, N, and O elements in the catalyst, consistent with the results of XRD and EDS mapping. The Co 2p spectrum in Fig. 6e shows two metal Co peaks at 777.09 eV and 792.20 eV, along with two additional peaks at 779.51 eV and 781.33 eV corresponding to Co2+ and Co3+, respectively, with oscillating satellites at 792.20 eV and 802.11 eV Compared to the Co 2p spectrum in Co1Ni1@NC, there are no distinct metal peaks corresponding to Co0, indicating a reduced Co° content. The introduction of Mo ions facilitates charge transfer between Co and Mo, promoting the formation of the bimetallic nitride Co3Mo3 N instead of the reduction of Co and Mo to their metallic states. This alters the electronic environment due to the synergistic effect between the metals, resulting in a shift of the Co 2p characteristic peaks towards lower binding energy, compared to Co 2p in Co@NC (Fig. S6) [21,58,59]. This suggests the presence of electron transfer between Co and Co3Mo3 N in the Co1Mo1@NC catalyst, exhibiting a certain synergistic effect. In the Mo 3d spectrum in Fig. 5f, the peak positions at (229.43, 232.78), (231.41, 234.46), and (232.93, 236.08 eV) correspond to Mo2+, Mo4+, and Mo6+, respectively. The N 1 s spectrum in Fig. 6g reveals a peak at 397.37 eV, indicating N atoms coordinated with Mo atoms, forming N-Mo coordination, further confirming the successful synthesis of nitrides. Previous studies have shown that Mo2+, Mo4+, and Mo6+ mainly originate from Mo2 N and Co3Mo3 N, with Co3Mo3 N being more active in ammonia decomposition than Mo2N [60]. Therefore, the high activity of the Co1Mo1@NC catalyst can be attributed to its main components, Co3Mo3 N, and the synergistic interaction between Co and Co3Mo3N. Figs. 7 a and 7b employs H2-TPR to analyze the interaction between the active component and the support, thereby assessing the catalytic activity [40,61–63]. In the case of Co1Ni1@NC, the H2-TPR reveals major reduction peaks at 512 and 569 °C, corresponding to the reduction of CO 2+ to Co0 and Ni2+ to Ni0, respectively. Additionally, the reduction peak of reduction in Co1Ni1@NC bimetallic catalyst fall between those of Co2Ni1@NC and Co1Ni2@NC metal catalysts, indicating suitable interactions between CoNi alloy particles and the carbon support, resulting in high stability and catalytic performance. For Co1Mo1@NC catalyst, the main reduction peaks occur at 378 and 672 °C, corresponding to the reduction of CO 2+ to Co0 and Mo6+ to Mo4+ respectively. Similarly, the reduction peak of the Co1Mo1@NC bimetallic catalyst falls between those of Co2Mo1@NC and Co1Mo2@NC, indicating suitable interactions between Co and Co3Mo3 N alloy particles and the carbon support, resulting in improved catalyst stability and catalytic performance. Fig. 7C and 7D employ CO2-TPD to analyze the basicity of the catalyst. The basicity of supported catalysts is determined based on the temperature range of CO2 desorption from basic sites. Generally, Lewis basic sites are categorized as weak basicity (<200 °C), medium basicity (200–450 °C), and strong basicity (450–600 °C) [64]. Co1Ni1@NC exhibits medium basicity at 437 °C, similar to Co2Ni1@NC, Co1Ni2@NC, and their basicity. In the case of CoMo@NC, the addition of Mo salt increases the number and strength of basic sites. The catalysts exhibit a considerable number of strong basic sites between 450 and 600 °C, with Co1Mo1@NC having the highest number of basic sites. Strong basic centers can provide their electrons to the surface of active sites, facilitating the recombination and desorption of surface nitrogen atoms. Enhanced basicity is crucial for the catalytic activity of active metals, promoting the recombination of adsorbed nitrogen atoms during ammonia dehydrogenation and ammonia decomposition-related electron donation [65,66]. Therefore, the appropriate alkalinity is one of the reasons why the Co1Mo1@NC catalyst exhibits higher catalytic activity. 4 Conclusions To address the high cost and scarcity of noble metal catalysts for ammonia decomposition, a series of highly efficient and stable non-noble metal CoM@NC (M = Ni, Mo) bimetallic catalysts are synthesized in this study, featuring N-doped carbon frameworks embedded in ZIF-67 templates. The study focuses on the influence of varying metals (Ni and Mo) and their ratios with cobalt on the catalytic performance of the catalysts. The research findings reveal that the metal composition and ratios in bimetallic catalysis significantly influence its catalytic performance. In comparison to the CoNi@NC catalysts, CoMo@NC catalysts demonstrates superior performance in ammonia decomposition. Specifically, Co1Mo1@NC achieves an ammonia conversion rate of 97.57 % at 550 °C under the conditions of 30,000 mL h-1 g-1 cat, with a hydrogen production rate of 32.66 H2 g-1 cat min-1. Even under extreme conditions of 600 °C and 60,000 mL h-1 g-1 cat for 300 h, the ammonia decomposition activity of the Co1Mo1@NC catalyst remains stable. This phenomenon is attributed to several factors: 1) the larger specific surface area and porous layered petal-like structure of the Co1Mo1@NC catalyst, facilitating rapid electron transfer and offering abundant reaction sites for ammonia decomposition; 2) the synergistic effect between Co and the bimetallic nitride Co3Mo3 N, which provides more M-N active sites; and 3) the strong alkalinity of the Co1Mo1@NC catalyst. Therefore, controlling the synthesis of Co-M bimetallic catalysts with excellent catalytic performance can be applied to ammonia decomposition for hydrogen production, providing an effective strategy for enhancing the activity and stability of non-precious metal Co-based catalysts. This approach can be extended to the development of catalysts based on nitrogen-doped carbon frameworks doped with multiple metal species, showing promising potential in energy storage and catalysis applications. coredata.dc:description: Ammonia, as a promising hydrogen carrier, has garnered significant attention due to its high energy density, ease of transportation, and non-toxic decomposition process, and the absence of harmful by-products. Ammonia can produce hydrogen through the thermochemical ammonia decomposition reaction, requiring efficient catalysts. Although Ru-based catalysts exhibit high activity, their application is limited due to their high cost and scarcity. Here, a series of highly efficient and stable non-noble CoM@NC (M = Ni, Mo) bimetallic catalysts with N-doped carbon frameworks embedded in ZIF-67 templates are synthesized for ammonia decomposition to hydrogen. The impact of non-noble metal composition and ratios on the performance of ammonia decomposition is primarily investigated. The experimental results show that: 1) The catalytic performance of the ammonia decomposition catalyst can be regulated by adjusting the catalyst composition and metal ratios; 2) Compared to CoNi@NC catalysts, CoMo@NC catalysts exhibit superior performance in ammonia decomposition; 3) Co1Mo1@NC catalyst achieves an ammonia conversion rate of 97.57 % at 550 °C under the conditions of 30,000 mL h-1 g-1 cat, with a hydrogen production rate of 32.66 mmol H2 g-1 cat min-1; 4) Even in extreme conditions of 600 °C and 60,000 mL h-1 g-1 cat for 300 h, the ammonia decomposition activity of the Co1Mo1@NC catalyst remains unchanged; 5) The excellent catalytic performance of Co1Mo1@NC catalyst is attributed to its porous layered petal-like structure providing a fast pathway for electron transfer, the presence of Co3Mo3 N bimetallic nitride with more Mo-N active sites, and its strong alkaline nature. This study offers significant importance for the further development of non-noble metal cobalt-based catalysts for ammonia decomposition.
